newsitem.title: INDIA: Profit-taking checks India stocks steep ascent.
newsitem.headline: Profit-taking checks India stocks steep ascent.

text.p: ** (1230 GMT) - Indian shares erase day's sharp gains to
end marginally higher in a day of wild swings
** Bombay index ends 13.56 points, or 0.35 pct, higher at
3,871.05, off 4,007.91-intra-day high
** Profit-booking by local players trims early spurt,
foreign funds only scattered buyers in select stocks
** Government's 1997/98 (April-March) budget on Friday
widely acclaimed as path-breaking and pro-market
** National bourse index ends 0.43 pct up at 1,107.70
** Delhi index rises 11.90 points to 823.73, Calcutta
2.65 pts to 471.59 and Madras 108.07 pts to 3,706.71
Post-budget euphoria gripping Indian bourses ran into profit-taking on Monday, and prices ended near the day's lows after some wild swings, dealers said.

The benchmark 30-share index of the Bombay Stock Exchange (BSE) ended with a net gain of 13.56 points, or 0.35 percent at 3,871.05, erasing a sharp 150.42 points, or 3.9 percent rally which rocketed the index above the 4,000 mark.

"I guess there is a certain amount of profit-taking which is quite healthy. It doesn't look like there is a trend reversal," said Prashant Purker, head of institutional sales at Peregrine Capital India Ltd.
Analysts said benchmark stocks lagged in the market rally as buying interest switched to smaller capitalised stocks, with investors finding cheap values at current prices.
"This reaction is quite healthy. It only gives opportunity for more people to enter the market," said the head of dealing at a foreign securities firm who did not wish to be named.
"I expect the market to form a bottom in the next few days and break the all-time high of 4,643 reached in September 1995."
The breadth and focus of Finance Minister P. Chidambaram's 1997/98 (April-March) budget last Friday, boosted market confidence and sent investors on a buying spree, traders said.
BHEL closed 13.25 rupees up at 285.0, Colgate 15.0 to 355.0 and Arvind Mills 7.75 to 156.25. Among pivotals, Reliance fell 4.50 rupees to 305.50 and SBI 7.75 to 324.0.
"Foreign funds will go in for large market-capitalised stocks. Having missed the rally, they must be frustrated." Ajit Dayal, director at Quantum Financial Services, said.

"Anyone who doubted that reforms were on the stumbling block are now silent. The coalition has given us a fantastic budget," Quantum's Dayal said. He forecast the index would hit 4,500 points within three months.
-- Anshuman Daga, Bombay equities desk +91-22-265 9000
